chapter.title: Eclipse Setup
chapter.para: The most current version of Eclipse is Juno, Service Release 1. The Juno SR1 release has some significant performance issues that makes it undesirable over the Eclipse Indigo SR2 release. However, Eclipse recently released a performance patch for Juno SR1 and has plans to release SR2 with those patches in the Feb 2013 timeframe. The instructions below will ask you to download the Juno SR1 release and apply the performance patches. If Juno SR2 is released within the first few weeks of class -- please feel free to use that version. If either Juno SR1+patch or SR2 have issues -- please feel free to drop back to Indigo SR2 http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-java-ee-developers/indigosr2 - look to the right side of the page).

section.title: Download and Install Eclipse Juno Service Release 1 (SR2 if available)

listitem.para: Download Eclipse IDE for JavaEE Developers http://eclipse.org/downloads
Unzip the downloaded archive.
listitem.programlisting:
$ tar xzf ~/Downloads/eclipse-jee-juno-SR1-linux-gtk.tar.gz
$ ls eclipse about_files artifacts.xml dropins eclipse.ini features libcairo-swt.so p2 readme about.html configuration eclipse epl-v10.html icon.xpm notice.html plugins

listitem.para: Create a shortcut for starting Eclipse
Start Eclipse
Follow the resolution instructions documented at the following site http://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform_UI/Juno_Performance_Investigation.

section.title: Define JDK location
section.para: Eclipse will default to the JRE when launching most tools/applications. Sometimes this can be an issue and requires a JDK. Add the JDK and make it your default JRE.

listitem.para: Window->Preferences->Java->Installed JREs
press Add..->Standard VM and reference the JDK instance you installed earlier
Make the new JDK VM your default

section.title: Setup Maven Eclipse Integration (m2e)
section.para: m2e is a plugin installed into Eclipse that configures Eclipse based on the Maven pom.xml configuration. When adjusting your builds, you should always define changes within the Maven pom.xml and rely on m2e to translate that into Eclipse. Any changes added directly to Eclipse will not be seen by the command-line build.

listitem.para: Enter "m2e"
Installer "Maven Integration for Eclipse" by Eclipse.org
Complete the installation steps for Maven Integration for Eclipse
Register your Maven installation with m2e
Navigate and select the MAVEN_HOME directory installed earlier
Re-select the internal Maven instance as the default
Add the Java Package Explorer to the JavaEE Perspective. I find this easier to work with than the Project Explorer used by default in the JavaEE perspective.
Select Window->Show View->Other->Java->Package Explorer.
Drag the Package Explorer to the panel with the Project Explorer
Select Top Level Elements->Working Sets from the down-facing triangle in the top-right corner of the Package Explorer.
Create a New Java Working Set and call it "class-examples"
Press OK
Import the class examples into Eclipse as a Maven Project
Right click on "class-examples" in the Package Explorer and select Import...->Maven->Existing Maven Projects
Browse to the project area where you performed the Git checkout earlier and select the javase5Enhancements folder.
Select Next to have the current project(s) added to the selected working set.

note.para: There will be an extra panel that appears the first time you import a project with a new maven plugin. Allow Eclipse to setup any that it knows about, discover ones that may be new, or resolve later for those that it cannot find. There will be unsigned content warnings for most of the plugins. Eclipse will want to restart after installing any new plugins.

listitem.para: Build and test the application using Run As->Maven Install by right clicking on any of the project folders.

note.para: If you receive the following error
note.programlisting: [ERROR] No compiler is provided in this environment. Perhaps you are running on a JRE rather than a JDK?
note.para: add the following '-vm' option to your eclipse.ini file -- pointing to your javaw executable in the JDK directory, restart Eclipse, and retry.

listitem.para: Try also Run As->JUnit Test.

section.title: Setup EGit Eclipse Team Provider
section.para: You can use the command line Git to functionally clone the remote repository and update your local copy. However, having Git integrated into Eclipse allows the plugin to make Eclipse transition easier between one checked out branch to another or correctly react to an updated branch. To do this -- install the EGit plugin.

listitem.para: Open the Eclipse Marketplace panel using Help->Eclipse Marketplace
Type EGit into the seach field and press Go

Click Install for the EGit - Git Team Provider. This will end up selecting both EGit and JGit. JGit is the underlying pure Java interface for Git. EGit is the portion that integrates the capability into Eclipse.
Complete the installation process
Right click on the ejavase5Enhancements project imported earlier and select Team->Share Project...->Git->Use of create repository in parent folder of project->Finish
[(branch-name)] should now be displayed to the right of the project name

section.title: Setup JBoss Eclipse Integration
section.para: Add the following repository to your Eclipse instance and install the plugin

listitem.para: Open the Eclipse Marketplace panel using Help->Eclipse Marketplace
Type JBoss into the seach field and press Go
Click Install for the JBoss Tools (Juno)

Complete the installation steps for JBoss Tools. There are a lot of tools in the repository. Not all of them are needed for class or obvious how to use them without more investigation. Choose the following minimal set.
JBoss JAX-RS Tools
JBoss AS Tools
JBoss WebServices Tools

note.para: You will receive a warning about the content within the plugin being unsigned.

listitem.para: Define a Server Instance for JBoss AS 7
Open the JavaEE Perspective
Select "new server wizard..." in the Servers panel
Select JBossAS 7.1
Set HOME to your jboss-as-7.1.1.Final directory using the Browse button on the next panel
Name the server "standalone" and leave the to match the default "standalone.xml" configuration file.
Set the JRE to the default 'real' JRE

Review options. Note that I generally start my server externally so that standard output does not compete with my other actions within Eclipse. However, there are pros and cons to both methods and I will start you with internally launched here.
Start the server by right clicking on it and selecting Start
